description: From Latin hecatombē, from Ancient Greek ἑκατόμβη (hekatómbē), from ἑκατόν (hekatón, “hundred”) + βοῦς (boûs, “ox”).

entries.meaning: (Ancient Greece, Ancient Rome) A great feast and public sacrifice to the gods, originally of a hundred oxen.
examples: For the god they speedily stationed the sacred hecatomb all in good order surrounding the well-built altar.

entries.meaning: (by extension) Any great sacrifice; a great number of people, animals or things, especially as sacrificed or destroyed; a large amount.
examples: In Conquest's opinion, the visceral reaction to Nazism entails a verdict that it was morally worse than Stalinism, even if its eventual hecatomb was a less colossal one.
